summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General with Dr. , the former chief psychologist at MCC New York, as part of the investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein. Dr. details her interactions with Epstein, his psychological assessments, housing decisions, and the events leading up to his death on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: High-profile inmate at MCC New York who died by suicide on August 10, 2019. Discussed his psychological assessments, housing, behavior, and interactions with staff.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.role: Chief Psychologist at MCC New York
persons.context: The witness being interviewed. She was the chief psychologist at MCC and had direct professional interactions with Jeffrey Epstein regarding his mental health assessments and housing recommendations.

persons.name: Special Agent
persons.context: One of the primary interviewing agents conducting the OIG investigation into Epstein's death.

persons.name: Senior Special Agent
persons.context: The other interviewing agent present and identified as the case agent for the OIG investigation.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: Central office psychologist who contacted Dr. regarding Epstein's static risk factors (high-profile, sex offender) and monitored his status.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in the SHU. A former law enforcement officer facing murder charges. Involved in the July 23 incident where Epstein was found with a ligature mark.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: Psychologist who conducted suicide risk assessments on Epstein, including stepping him down from suicide watch to psychological observation on July 24.

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: The warden at MCC who made the decision not to house Epstein in the high-security Ten South unit and was involved in housing decisions.

persons.name: Associate Warden
persons.context: Associate warden who was consulted by Dr. when she stepped Epstein down from suicide watch.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: Lieutenant in the Special Housing Unit who Dr. described as very regimented and who would pass on Epstein's complaints.

persons.name: Paul Manafort
persons.context: A high-profile inmate previously housed in the Cadre unit. Epstein expressed a desire to be housed in the same unit.

persons.name: Inmate Reyes
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate after he returned to the SHU in late July. He was removed from the institution on August 9, leaving Epstein alone.

connections.description: Dr. , as chief psychologist, was responsible for Epstein's psychological assessments, suicide risk evaluations, and making housing recommendations for him.
Epstein and Tartaglione were cellmates in the SHU. Epstein initially accused Tartaglione of assaulting him on July 23, but later expressed willingness to cell with him again.
Dr. , the central office suicide prevention coordinator, monitored Epstein's case and was in contact with Dr. regarding his risk factors.
Dr. was the chief psychologist and Dr. was a forensic psychologist on her staff. They consulted on Epstein's case, particularly regarding stepping him down from suicide watch.
The warden had ultimate authority over housing decisions for Epstein, including the decision not to place him in the high-security Ten South unit.
Epstein was housed with inmate Reyes in the SHU after returning from psychological observation. Reyes was removed on August 9, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

events.title: Epstein's Initial Intake and Placement on Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein completed the Psychological Services Intake Questionnaire (PSIQ) and marked nothing concerning. Due to his high-profile status and sex offense charges, Dr. placed him on suicide watch as a precautionary measure.

events.title: Ligature Incident and Second Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell with a loose noose around his neck. He was placed on suicide watch. He initially told staff his cellmate Tartaglione tried to kill him, but later became vague about what happened.

events.title: Epstein Stepped Down to Psychological Observation
events.description: Dr. conducted a lengthy suicide risk assessment and stepped Epstein down from suicide watch to psychological observation, as he denied suicidality and had future plans.

events.title: Epstein Returned to SHU
events.description: Dr. transitioned Epstein back to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) from psychological observation, with the condition he be housed with a cellmate.

events.title: SHU Meeting and Last Contact
events.description: Dr. attended the SHU meeting and conducted rounds. She saw Epstein with his cellmate (Reyes), who appeared in good spirits and reported getting along with his cellmate. She left for vacation after this.

events.title: Cellmate Removed, Epstein Left Alone
events.description: Epstein's cellmate, Reyes, was removed from the institution (transferred out). Epstein was left in a single cell overnight, contrary to psychology's strong recommendation that he always have a cellmate.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found deceased in his cell at MCC New York. Dr. believes he died by suicide, likely due to hopelessness after bad legal news and being left alone without a cellmate.

events.title: OIG Interview with Dr.
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with Dr. as part of its investigation into Epstein's death.

locations: One Battery Park Plaza, New York, NY (OIG New York Field Office)
Cadre Unit (dorm-style unit at MCC for sentenced inmates with short terms)
keyFacts: Psychology strongly and consistently recommended Epstein have a cellmate at all times when not in a high-security camera unit, to decrease isolation and provide a rescue opportunity.
Epstein was left alone in his cell on the night of August 9-10, 2019, after his cellmate was removed. The label for his former cellmate was still on the door, and no new cellmate was provided.
Dr. stated that had she known Epstein signed a new will on August 8, she would have considered it a major red flag and likely placed him back on psychological observation.
The warden decided not to house Epstein in the high-security Ten South unit (with cameras), opting instead for the SHU with a cellmate. Dr. was informed of this decision but not consulted.
Dr. believes Epstein died by suicide, citing factors like receiving devastating legal news, feeling hopeless, and the opportunity presented by being alone in his cell.
